items.title: Royal Commission into Bondi Beach terror attack needed, NSW premier says
items.description: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns is supporting calls for a Royal Commission to be held into the Bondi Beach terror attack, which claimed the lives of 15 innocent people.

items.title: Live: Bondi vigils continue as Anthony Albanese calls for unity
items.description: Hundreds of surf lifesavers have gathered on Bondi Beach to pay tribute to the victims of last Sunday's terrorist attack. Follow live.

items.title: In pictures: Surf lifesavers with heartfelt tribute to Bondi victims
items.description: Hundreds of surf lifesavers and lifeguards, many of whom responded to the Bondi terror attack, form a human chain in a moving tribute to the 15 people killed.

items.title: Two girls separated from their dad at Bondi is a scene hard to forget
items.description: These are the stories of everyday people who stepped up during dark times, and of a community coming together when two gunmen sought to tear them apart on December 14.

items.title: Albanese not the only one facing a reckoning over Bondi terror
items.description: While the prime minister will forever struggle to shed the perception that he was too slow to recognise the threat to Australia's Jewish community, he is taking action.

items.title: Live: US politicians slam first release of Epstein files but Trump makes no mention in 90-minute speech
items.description: A trove of documents about the investigation into sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and his co-conspirator, Ghislaine Maxwell, has been published. Follow live as we analyse the files and the fallout.

items.title: 'Say she's 18': Inside the first batch of Epstein files
items.description: The US Department of Justice today released thousands of files it holds on late sex offender and disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein. Here's what's been uncovered in just a few hours.

items.title: Extreme heat, humidity and storms ahead of Christmas Day
items.description: Australia is experiencing a smorgasbord of wild weather in the lead-up to Christmas, featuring extreme heat, humidity, severe thunderstorms, and tropical storms all on the cards.

items.title: Live: Cummins removes Root again after Marnus's miracle lights up Ashes
items.description: Australia can win the Ashes faster than any team in over 100 years after setting England a record 435 runs to win the third Test at Adelaide Oval and keep the series alive. Follow live.

items.title: Live: Jake Paul knocked out by AJ in sixth round
items.description: Jake Paul and former unified heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua meet in their highly-criticised boxing match in Miami on Netflix. Follow live.

items.title: US strikes dozens of IS targets in Syria, officials say
items.description: Described as "a declaration of vengeance" by US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the strikes come after Donald Trump vowed retaliation for an attack on US personnel.

items.title: Fisherman spots a rare pink platypus in a remote Victorian river
items.description: In a remote river in Victoria's east, a fisherman says he has encountered an ultra-rare pink platypus, one of only a handful ever sighted in the past 200 years.

items.title: Grace Tame fights against a legal loophole frustrating abuse survivors
items.description: In every Australian state and the NT, churches cannot be held vicariously liable for historical child sexual abuse perpetrated by their priests. Grace Tame is leading the charge for change.

items.title: How a desolate Scottish isle is providing a crucial Olympics resource
items.description: For all intents and purposes, Ailsa Craig looks like it has nothing to offer the human experience. But on its desolate shores, golden dreams are quietly being mined.

items.title: How 'half-brained' thieves snatched a $50m Picasso in under four minutes
items.description: The 2007 Brazilian heist was not the last time a nimble thief made off with a Picasso. And as many Melburnians know, it certainly wasn't the first.

items.title: 'Why on Earth would we do it?': This scientist is trying to figure out kissing
items.description: Why is swapping saliva something all human societies have normalised? Turns out kissing isn't just a human thing — all sorts of species appear to kiss, and new research suggests Neanderthals did it too.

items.title: Parents grapple with Australia's social media ban
items.description: For some parents, the social media bans for under-16s have come as a relief. But others say they are fuelling conflict.

items.title: Passenger numbers fall short on $2.9 billion Western Sydney light rail line
items.description: While rider numbers fell short of expectations in 2025, next year the number of trips taken on the Parramatta Light Rail is expected to double.

items.title: Why this 'powerhouse' of women's Aussie Rules is at risk of folding
items.description: Melbourne University is the latest women’s Aussie Rules club fighting for survival, but it is hoping intervention from an AFL executive can turn the club’s fortunes around.

items.title: 'Lion', Kubrick fan, artist: Meet the A-League's most interesting coach
items.description: In a team struggling to retain fans, in a league battling for attention, newly appointed Perth Glory coach Adam Griffiths may just be the man with the answers for both problems.

items.title: Fight on to save these 'vacuum cleaners of the river' from extinction
items.description: A team of environmental experts, Indigenous rangers and conservation detection dogs is working on recovering the population of native freshwater turtles.

items.title: Dreams shattered as 140 Zone RV caravan customers' worst fears realised
items.description: About 140 customers of Zone RV have been told they will not be receiving their caravans after the company collapsed.

items.title: Tobacco shop owner 'refuses to cooperate' with police despite shakedown sign
items.description: Shop owners in the northern Victorian town of Swan Hill say they are concerned after a threatening note was left outside a store selling tobacco, demanding the owner "contact the commission".

items.title: Man burned in gin fire loses court case against distillery
items.description: A work health and safety case against a distillery in Perth, northern Tasmania, is dismissed.

items.title: Deaths of two Aboriginal brothers with disability reveals systemic failures
items.description: The NT coroner makes nine recommendations following an inquest into the deaths of two disabled Aboriginal brothers who spent a number of years homeless in Alice Springs.
